metadata.case_name: General Manager, Bhilai Steel Project v. Unions

facts.text: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946 (Central Standing Orders Act) came into force on April 23, 1946.

C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 enacted, extending to whole of Madhya Pradesh. Sections 2 to 61 came into force in all industries except certain specified, via notification dated November 20, 1947.
Notification dated July 22, 1958 amended previous notification, making Sections 2 to 61 of 1947 Act applicable to Steel Industry at Bhilai with effect from August 1, 1958.
Madhya Pradesh Industrial Workmen (Standing Orders) Act, 1959 (Act No. XIX of 1959) passed, repealing Section 30 of 1947 Act, came into force on December 31, 1960.
Draft standing orders submitted by General Manager, Bhilai Steel Project to Certifying Officer (Mr. I.B. Sanyal) under Central Standing Orders Act on June 9, 1960.

Act XIX of 1959 contains proviso to Section 1(3): does not apply to industrial establishment under control of Central Government without consent of Central Government. No consent given for Bhilai Steel Project.
Bhilai Steel Industry is an industrial establishment under the control of the Central Government.
Madhya Pradesh Industrial Establishment (Standing Orders) Act, 1961 (Act No. XXVI of 1961) came into force on November 25, 1961, repealing Act XIX of 1959.
Mr. I.B. Sanyal, Certifying Officer under Central Standing Orders Act, certified the draft standing orders on August 6, 1962, overruling Unions' objection on jurisdiction.
Madhya Pradesh Act 5 of 1962 amended Act XXVI of 1961 by adding proviso to Section 2(1) excluding undertakings under authority of Central Government, assented by President on April 29, 1962.
Unions (respondents) appealed to Industrial Court, Madhya Pradesh against certification order.
Industrial Court, Madhya Pradesh held Mr. Sanyal had no jurisdiction, Labour Commissioner MP competent, set aside certification order as void on November 16, 1962.
Present appeals filed in Supreme Court by special leave against Industrial Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Certifying Officer under the Central Standing Orders Act had jurisdiction to certify the standing orders for Bhilai Steel Project on August 6, 1962, despite lacking it on submission date June 9, 1960.
Whether the Central Standing Orders Act or Madhya Pradesh Acts applied to Bhilai Steel Industry on August 6, 1962.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if Certifying Officer lacked jurisdiction on June 9, 1960 when draft submitted, he acquired jurisdiction before certification on August 6, 1962, making certification valid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Municipal Board, Pushkar v. State Transport Authority, Rajasthan Others; principle that invalid application becomes valid upon acquiring jurisdiction

petitioner_arguments.text: Central Standing Orders Act became applicable to Bhilai Steel Industry before August 6, 1962, excluding MP Acts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Provisos in MP Acts XIX/1959 and XXVI/1961 as amended

respondent_arguments.text: Certifying Officer (Mr. Sanyal) had no jurisdiction; Labour Commissioner, Madhya Pradesh competent under MP Act.
Attempt to argue Bhilai Steel not under Central Government control, but not permitted as not raised earlier.

court_reasoning.text: If officer acquires jurisdiction before certification, even if lacking at submission, certification valid; application deemed renewed.
MP Act XIX/1959 did not apply to Bhilai due to proviso (no Central consent) and Bhilai under Central control; repealed s.30 of 1947 Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: From Dec 31, 1960, neither 1947 Act s.30 nor 1959 Act applied

court_reasoning.text: MP Act XXVI/1961 applied from Nov 25, 1961 but ceased on April 29, 1962 due to amendment excluding Central undertakings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Central Act applied from April 29, 1962 onwards

court_reasoning.text: Industrial Court's reliance on s.25 MP General Clauses Act misplaced; notification inconsistent with 1959 Act proviso.

holdings.text: Certification by Certifying Officer under Central Act on August 6, 1962 valid as jurisdiction acquired before that date.
Central Standing Orders Act applied to Bhilai Steel Industry on and after April 29, 1962; MP Acts excluded.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Board, Pushkar v. State Transport Authority, Rajasthan Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports that jurisdiction acquired before certification validates order even if lacking at application

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Applicable to Bhilai Steel Project on and after April 29, 1962; Certifying Officer competent

statutes_cited.name: C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: s.30 repealed by 1959 Act; earlier applied via 1958 notification to Bhilai

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Industrial Workmen (Standing Orders) Act, 1959 (Act XIX)
statutes_cited.relevance: Did not apply to Central controlled Bhilai without consent; repealed 1947 s.30

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Industrial Establishment (Standing Orders) Act, 1961 (Act XXVI)
statutes_cited.relevance: Temporarily applied but excluded by 1962 amendment

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Act 5 of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended 1961 Act to exclude Central undertakings from April 29, 1962

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Did not save 1958 notification as inconsistent with 1959 Act

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, set aside Industrial Court order holding certification void, as Certifying Officer had jurisdiction by August 6, 1962. Directed Industrial Court to hear and dispose Unions' appeals on merits regarding other objections.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside Industrial Court order; remand for merits hearing

key_quotes.text: We have no doubt that if before the actual date of certification Mr. Sanyal as the Certifying Officer under the Central Standing Orders Act had acquired jurisdiction the certification cannot be held to be void merely because on the date when the orders were submitted before him he had no jurisdiction.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle on acquiring jurisdiction post-submission

key_quotes.text: There is no escape therefore from the conclusion that on and after December 31, 1960, the Bhilai Steel Industry was governed as regards the matter of standing orders by the Central Standing Orders Act of 1946.
key_quotes.speaker: court
